occurrences.line_text: And from her sory hart few heauie words forth sigh't.
That he these words burst forth; Ah sory boy,
Here in this bottle (sayd the sory Mayd)
But Calidore, though no lesse sory wight,
Right sory I, (saide then Sir Calidore,)
And souce so sore, that they the heauens affray:
That with his souce, which none enduren dare,
Till sadly soucing on the sandie shore,
They slay the Soudan, driue his wife
That of his way he had no souenaunce,
And all thy wrongs will wipe out of my souenaunce.
And she her selfe of beautie soueraigne Queene,
The Fort, that Ladies hold in soueraigne dread.
And doen their seruice to that soueraigne Dame,
O pardon me, my soueraigne Lord, to show
That with her soueraigne powre, and scepter shene
The gifts of soueraigne bountie did embrace:
Till that him thus bespake their soueraigne Lord & sire.
A stately siege of soueraigne maiestye;
My liefe, my liege, my Soueraigne, my deare,
Of my most dreaded Soueraigne I recount,
O soueraigne Queene, whose prayse I would endite,
Of royall maiesty and soueraigne name;
The soueraigne weede betwixt two marbles plaine
Her soueraigne bounty, and celestiall hew,
With which her soueraigne mercy thou doest quight?
She did enuy that soueraigne salue, in secret store.
Ioue laught on Venus from his soueraigne see,
The shyning glory of your soueraigne light,
And of all Asie bore the soueraigne crowne,
To sit in second seat of soueraigne king,
He said; ï¿½ soueraigne Lord that sit'st on hye,
To see him in his soueraigne maiestee,
But to that sacred Saint my soueraigne Queene,
For soueraine hope, which in his helpe he had:
And high disdaine, whenas his soueraine Dame
Wherewith he goeth to that soueraine Queene,
And wonder of her beautie soueraine,
A trickling streame of Balme, most soueraine
Withhold, O soueraine Prince, your hasty hond
Right well I wote most mighty Soueraine,
To serue againe his soueraine Elfin Queene,
Whereof he crau'd redresse. My Soueraine,
And soueraine moniment of mortall vowes,
Art Lord, and eke of nature Soueraine,
Or grace of earthly Prince so soueraine,
Conceiue such soueraine glory, and great bountihed?
Thy name, Ã´ soueraine Queene, to blazon farre away.
Thy name Ã´ soueraine Queene, thy realme and race,
Locrine was left the soueraine Lord of all;
Deposed was from Princedome soueraine,
Was of the Britons first crownd Soueraine:
Hereto perforce. But ï¿½ dred Soueraine
Whose soueraine beautie hath no liuing pere,
So is his soueraine honour raisde to heauens hight.
They pourd in soueraine balme, and Nectar good,
For Tryphon of sea gods the soueraine leach is hight.
And soueraine fauour towards chastity,
And bad before his soueraine Lord appere:
And tribute eke withall, as to his Soueraine.
The controuerse of beauties soueraine grace;
Held vertue for it selfe in soueraine awe:
Dew'd with her drops of bountie Soueraine,
To none, but to the seas sole Soueraine.
Whose soueraine powre is herein most exprest,
That soueraine Queene, that mightie Emperesse,
Ne any may his soueraine power shonne,
That Iustice was a God of soueraine grace,
And soueraine grace, with which her royall crowne
All to his hands, and gaue him soueraine powre
Vnto his soueraine Queene her suite for to commend.
From heauenly seedes of bounty soueraine,
As in your selfe, O soueraine Lady Queene,
Then pardon me, most dreaded Soueraine,
To my dread Soueraine, when I it assayd,
That in her soueraine lyking he dwelt euermore.
Did boast her beautie had such soueraine might,
Y e gentle Ladies, in whose soueraine powre
Did for their soueraine goddesse her esteeme,
And in her soueraine Maiesty to sit,
Diuine resemblaunce, beauty soueraine rare,
Sith it is shrined in my Soueraines brest,
My glorious Soueraines goodly auncestrie,
Ne heritage of natiue soueraintie,
To haue a pere in part of soueraintie,
And enuious of Vncles soueraintie,
Vnlesse the heauens them lift to lawfull soueraintie.
He maketh Kings to sit in souerainty;
A Goddesse of great powre and souerainty
Nepenthe is a drinck of souerayne grace,
Dread Souerayne Goddesse, that doest highest sit
And of her seruant make her souerayne Lord:
Say on my souerayne Ladie, and be bold;
There shall ye see my souerayne Lady Queene
Thus she did sit in souerayne Maiestie,
So sitting high in dreaded souerayntie,
Sought through the world, and suffered so much ill,
Armed to point, sought backe to turne againe;
And creeping sought way in the weedy gras:
And with the Lady backward sought to wend;
He passed forth, and new aduenture sought;
Through woods and wastnesse wide him daily sought;
But subtill Archimag, that Vna sought
He sought all round about, his thirstie blade
And far abroad for straunge aduentures sought:
To Faerie lond, where yet it may be seene, if sought.
Through euery rowme he sought, and euery bowr,
Yt nought too deare I deemd, while so my dear I sought.
Him so I sought, and so at last I found
And thenceforth were renowmd, & sought from place to place.
Accord of friends, consent of parents sought,
And hellish fury all enragd, I sought
Then loe, where bound she sits, who[m]; thou hast sought,
His precious horne, sought of his enimies
But soone as Furor was enlargd, she sought
He that his sorrow sought through wilfulnesse,
Where she was rowing, and for passage sought:
Thenceforth she sought for helps, to cloke her crime withall.
Whom he had long time sought with fruitlesse suit:
Sith of that Goddesse I haue sought the sight,
And many good knights slaine, that haue vs sought to saue.
Sought with his raskall routs t'enclose them round,
That sought with her to lincke in marriage:
And each one sought his Lady to aggrate:
That haue twelue moneths sought one, yet no where can her find.
Yet with faire semblaunt sought to hide the breach,
That by well doing sought to honour to aspire.
Till that great Ladie thence away them sought,
That boy them sought, and vnto him did lend.
Amid the Ocean waues, ne was it sought
Then they which sought at first their helping hand,
Ne euer shruncke, ne euer sought to bayt
That earst was sought to decke both bed and bowre,
To seeke her louer (loue farre sought alas,)
Least that too farre ye haue your sorrow sought:
Full many waies she sought, but none could find,
Him forth through infinite endeuour to haue sought.
Bad eke attonce their charets to be sought;
First she him sought in Court, where most he vsed
She then the Citties sought from gate to gate,
Then in the countrey she abroad him sought,
Yet sought the saluage woods and forrests wyde,
That she her dearest sonne Cupido sought,
So long they sought, till they arriued were
All wayes she sought, him to restore to plight,
Sought by all meanes his dolour to prolong,
Her hard pursewd, and sought for to suppresse;
Is sought by Paridell.
She was the Lady selfe, whom he so long had sought.
Thenceforth to her he sought to intimate
Of th'inland folke, which sought him backe to driue,
Long he her sought, he sought her farre and nere,
Long he her sought, he sought her farre and nere,
But those two sought nought, but the present pray,
Endlesse renowm, that more then death is to be sought.
She sought to saue, as thing reseru'd from stealth;
That each of life sought others to depriue,
And sought to bring all things vnto decay;
His flaming furie sought to haue assuaged
And euermore sought Britomart to cleare.
So much the more she loued was and sought,
Where fast infixed, whilest he sought by slight
Ne followd on so fast, but rather sought
But if to match that Lady they had sought
And starting vp, streight for his armour sought:
In vaine he sought; for there he found it not;
So many Ladies sought, as shall appeare;
So many faire did see, as here he might haue sought.
Who likewise sought her louer long miswent,
I cal'd her loud, I sought her farre and neare;
There they her sought, and euery where inquired,
Which many a knight had sought so many a day.
Thenceforth I sought by secret meanes to worke
On which this shield, of many sought in vaine,
And which all Asia sought with vowes prophane,
Yet farre and neare the Nymph his mother sought,
Which him had sought through trouble & lo[n]g strife;
Yet had refusde a God that her had sought to wife.
Apollo came; who soone as he had sought
And all men sought their owne, and none no more;
Of whom he entrance sought, but was denide,
Long they her sought, yet no where could they finde her,
Which sought vnrighteousnesse, and iustice sold,
For there is nothing lost, that may be found, if sought.
And gan to doubt, least she him sought t'appeach
And all the wayes she sought, his loue for to haue wonne.
The more that she it sought to couer and to hyde.
Brought in vntimely houre, ere it was sought.
One day, when as she long had sought for ease
Each rowme she sought, but them all empty fond:
To seeke her loue, where he was to be sought;
Ne either sought the others strokes to shun,
She sought with ruth to salue his sad misfortunes sore.
And in their steede for other rayment sought,
Sought onely slaughter and auengement:
Still when he sought t'approch vnto him ny,
Yet when as foes enforst, or friends sought ayde,
Long sought the Prince, but when he found no more
Who her imprisond hath, and her life often sought.
That sought with lawlesse powre him to oppresse,
Of those, which sought his life for to empaire.
That all she sought, was mens good name to haue bereaued.
And sought to win his loue by all the meanes she might.
She hidden was, and sought her so long, as him list.
Which dwelt thereby, who sought her to affy
He sought him farre and neare, yet him no where he spyde.
And sought by all the meanes, that he could best,
That him not onely sought by open might
Sought to encompasse him on euery side,
And each sought to supply the office of her page.
And all the way the Prince sought to appease
Therefore descending backe in haste, he sought
And sought, by making signes, him to asswage:
Which lately sought his Lord for to displease:
That recreant knight, whose hated life I sought?
To seeke for safety, which long time she sought:
And sude and sought with all the seruice dew:
Long had he sought her, and through many a soyle
And leauing home, to roiall court I sought;
When he the loue of fayre Oenone sought,
Or wanton squirrels, in the woods farre sought,
Who rashly sought that, which I mote not see.
And sought her loue, by all the meanes he mote;
He sought the woods; but no man could see there;
He sought the plaines; but could no tydings heare.
Or how those theeues, whilest one sought her to hold,
Had from their maisters fled, & now sought hyre elswhere.
And all the secrets of their entrayles sought.
And life to feele, that long for death had sought;
Should know thereof, to slay he would haue sought,
With Claribell, whylest he that monster sought
Vppon the Souldan selfe, which it mayntained,
And sending to the Souldan in despight
Wherewith the Souldan all with furie fraught,
For the proud Souldan with presumpteous cheare,
So thought the Souldan in his follies threat,
Ne could the Souldan them from flying stay,
So was this Souldan rapt and all to rent,
That Ladies part, and to the Souldan lout:
Of that proud Souldan, whom he earst did slay.
The cruell Souldan, and with dreadfull fate
Vnto the Souldans court, her to present
That Damzell, led her to the Souldans right.
Well solast in that Souldans late delight,
The souldier may not moue from watchfull sted,
Haue made thee souldier of that Princesse bright,
O how great sorrow my sad soule assaid.
And layes the soule to sleepe in quiet graue?
And hellish anguish did his soule assaile,
So much the dart of sinfull guilt the soule dismayes.
That Mercy in the end his righteous soule might saue.
The feeble soule departing hence away.
And shewes the way, his sinfull soule to saue.
Whose sight my feeble soule doth greatly cheare:
Great woe and sorrow did her soule assay,
To hinder soule from her desired rest,
The weary soule from thence it would discharge;
The whiles my soule was soyld with foule iniquitie.
Bring the soule into captiuitie:
That the disdainfull soule he thence dispatcht,
His sinfull soule with desperate disdaine,
That the weake soule her seat did yet retaine,
And doth transfixe the soule with deathes eternall dart.
His strugling soule, and swelling throbs empeach
Fearing least from her cage the wearie soule would flit.
And the fraile soule in deepe delight nigh dround:
As if but one soule in them all did dwell,
The soule had sure out of his bodie riued,
For notwithstanding that one soule was reft,
It left; but that same soule, which therein dwelt,
So did one soule out of his bodie flie
And through his soule like poysned arrow perst,
As if he thought her soule to disentrayle.
And wound the soule it selfe with griefe vnkind:
His soule descended downe into the Stygian reame.
Which I to him as to my soule did beare;
For as the soule doth rule the earthly masse,
So loue of soule doth loue of bodie passe,
Grieu'd to the soule, and groning inwardly,
His groning soule vnto her place of punishment.
To call the soule backe to her home againe;
Who comming to that soule-diseased knight,
Whither the soules do fly of men, that liue amis.
Where many soules sit wailing woefully,
A worke of wondrous grace, and able soules to saue.
Of wretched soules, and helpe the helpelesse pore:
And many soules in dolours had fordonne:
The faultie soules from thence brought to his heauenly bowre.
They might appeare, when he their soules shall saue.
That long captiued soules from wearie thraldome free.
And trouble dying soules tranquilitee.
In which full many soules do endlesse waile and weepe.
In which the damned soules he did behold,
Some fit for reasonable soules t'indew,
So many Centaures drunken soules to hell,
As if their soules they would attonce haue rent
That if the happie soules, which doe possesse
That seem'd their soules they wold haue ryuen quight
Of these poore folk, whose soules with black dishonor
That swarmes of damned soules to hell he sends:
The caruer Holme, the Maple seeldom inward sound.
So sound he slept, that nought mought him awake.
And dreames, gan now to take more sound repast,
Vnder them neuer sat, ne wont there sound
His chearefull whistle merrily doth sound,
At last the trumpets Triumph sound on hie,
As giuing warning of th'vnwonted sound,
And all the way their merry pipes they sound,
Was neuer wight, that heard that shrilling sound,
He loudly brayd with beastly yelling sound,
Ne fleshly brest can armed be so sound,
Doth license him depart at sound of morning droome.
With that they heard a roaring hideous sound,
Then gan triumphant Trompets sound on hie,
Heard sound through all the Pallace pleasantly,
From lofty siege began these words aloud to sound.
A siluer sound, that heauenly musicke seemd to make.
Nor voyce sound mortall; I auow to thee,
When first I heard her horne sound with such ghastlinesse.
Which buzzed all about, and made such sound,
Who now shall giue vnto me words and sound,
A bridge of bras, whose sound heaue[n]s thunder seem'd to bee.
Etfsoones they heard a most melodious sound,
For nothing else might keepe her safe and sound;
Whose hideous horror and sad trembling sound
But wondrous massie and assured sound,
But hurt his hart, the which before was sound,
But did abide for euer chast and sound.
But were for other causes firme and sound;
That dreadfull sound the boasters hart did thrill,
Yet thou vile man, vile Scudamore art sound,
She heard a shrilling Trompet sound aloud,
In full straunge notes was sweetly heard to sound,
And euery part to safety full sound,
And to him cald; whose voices knowen sound
With warlike numbers and Heroicke sound,
That scarse he him vpheld from falling in a sound.
And trumpets sound to cease did them compell.
Till trumpets sound did warne them all to rest;
Where I with sound of trompe will also rest a whyle.
Whereto approaching nigh, they heard the sound
The hammers sound his senses did molest;
That Britomart heard not the shrilling sound,
There where through weary trauel she lay sleeping sou[n]d.
Some litle whispering, and soft groning sound.
Then was there heard a most celestiall sound,
No warre was knowne, no dreadfull trompets sound,
The trompets sound; then all together ronne.
Then did the trompets sound, and Iudges rose,
Bold Radigund with sound of trumpe on hight,
Their sound did reach vnto the heauens hight.
It was not long, before she heard the sound
And would no lenger treat, but bad them sound.
The Trumpets sound, and they together run
Yet did he murmure with rebellious sound,
As if the onely sound thereof she feard.
To whom he thus; She liueth sure and sound;
That foot of man might sound the bottome plaine,
The trompets sound, and they together goe,
For his faire vsage and conditions sound,
Who seeing him from farre, with piteous sound
Whiles yet his foe lay fast in sencelesse sound,
But a soft murmure, and confused sound
Approcht, him seemed that the merry sound
After a late forray, and slept full sound,
Vntill the damzell gan to wex more sound and strong.
The trumpets sounded, and they all arose,
The Trumpets sounded, and the field began;
So sounded the retraite, and drew his folke away.
And eke her champions glorie sounded ouer all.
Their murmuring small trompets sounden wide,
Like as a wayward childe, whose sounder sleepe
Yet in his soundest sleepe, his dayly feare
And to the Maydens sounding tymbrels sung
The siluer sounding instruments did meet
Where sounding loud a Trumpet from the wall,
To weeten what that trumpets sounding ment:
Where he slept soundly void of euill thought,
She soundly slept, & carefull thoughts did quite assoile.
And to his wife, that now full soundly slept,
Lay sleeping soundly in the bushes shade,
And oftentimes loud strokes, and ringing sounds
With fowle words tempring faire, soure gall with hony sweet.
Of those some were so from their sourse indewd
It was a faithlesse Squire, that was the sourse
Nor timely tides did driue out of their sluggish sourse.
And makes it seeme to haue some other sourse:
Loe where the villaine selfe, their sorrowes sourse,
Long Rhodanus, whose sourse springs from the skie;
From the first point of his appointed sourse,
Like as a water streame, whose swelling sourse
Of former daies mishap, his sorrowes wicked sourse.
Began to mitigate his swelling sourse,
That once hath failed of her souse full neare,
His dreadfull souse auoydes, it shunning light,
That seemed nought the souse thereof could beare,
That with the souse thereof full sore aghast,
Fayles of her souse, and passing by doth hurt no more.
From heaping stroakes, which thereon soused sore:
Oft soust in swelling Tethys saltish teare,
He stroke, he soust, he foynd, he hewd, he lasht,
Her selfe downe soust, she waked out of dread
His head and beard with sout were ill bedight,
Ouer the troubled South, that it shall make
Which all along the Southerne sea-coast lay,
The Easterne Saxons from the Southerne ny,
Nigh thirtie minutes to the Southerne lake;
The wise Southsayer seeing so sad sight,
And Glaucus, that wise southsayes vnderstood;
In Deheubarth that now South-wales is hight,
The watry Southwinde from the seabord cost
As incorrupted Nature did them sow,
Ne needs there Gardiner to set, or sow,
And sow vaine sorrow in a fruitlesse eare,
Of perfect loue did sow, that last forth brought
Who with few sowces of his yron flale,
For their bad Stuard neither plough'd nor sowed,
Who reapes the haruest sowen by his foe,
Sowen in bloudy field, and bought with woe:
Which she her selfe had sowen all about,
Therefore some thought, that those braue imps were sowen
As thicke as doth the seede after the sowers hand;
Lowde shriking him afflicted to the very sowle.
But ere she could him reach, the sinfull sowle
Arriu'd, where they in erth their fruitles bloud had sown.
True Loues are ofte[n] sown, but seldom grow on ground.
Whiles old Syluanus slept in shady arber sownd.
Till at the last he heard a dreadfull sownd,
The Gyant selfe dismaied with that sownd,
Soone as thy dreadfull trompe begins to sownd;
Thou doest awake, sleepe neuer he so sownd,
Of tall young men, all hable armes to sownd,
And gaue against his mother earth a gronefull sownd.
and reareth out of sownd.
And durst the depth of any water sownd.
But most that curre barking with bitter sownd,
A shrilling trompet sownded from on hye,
As when two billowes in the Irish sowndes,
Mixt with a murmuring winde, much like the sowne
Emongst the pumy stones, and made a sowne,
By fortune came, led with the troublous sowne:
With yelling outcries, and with shrieking sowne;
Whose fruitlesse liues were vnder furrow sowne,
A dram of sweet is worth a pound of sowre:
And her sowre breath abhominably smeld;
Right sowre, & feele the law, the which thou hast defast.
Sad, solemne, sowre, and full of fancies fraile
A thousand sowres hath tempred with one sweet,
So sore he sowst him on the compast creast,
And all so soyld, that none could him descry;
And soyld with durtie gore, that no man can
The whiles my soule was soyld with foule iniquitie.
Now are we come vnto my natiue soyle,
Polluted this same gentle soyle long time:
Had not Androgeus, false to natiue soyle,
Far fro my natiue soyle, that is by name
To this his natiue soyle thou backe shalt bring,
Vntill a straunger king from vnknowne soyle
And soyle which did deforme their liuely hew;
It sited was in fruitfull soyle of old,
Ruffled and fowly raid with filthy soyle,
Found it the fittest soyle for their abode,
Whiles neither lets the other touch the soyle,
As fresh as when it first was planted in the soyle.
Like warie Hynd within the weedie soyle,
Vnto the rocke, and there vpon the soyle
Out of the pleasant soyle, and citties glad,
In filthy durt, and left so in the loathely soyle.
Into the sea he droue quite from that soyle,
Long had he sought her, and through many a soyle
Yet seem'd the soyle both fayre and frutefull eft,
That such a cursed creature liues so long a space.
So hauing solaced themselues a space
The faithfull knight now grew in litle space,
So in short space they did to health restore
And cruell combat ioynd in middle space:
Hath now fast bound, me met in middle space,
Both yeeld, to stay your deadly strife a space.
That in short space he has them qualifyde,
At length they came into a larger space,
Woxe sore affraid, and standing still a space,
And couerd shield. Well kend him so farre space
The dales for shade, the hilles for breathing space,
And them awayted there a certaine space,
That in short space their foes they haue quite terrifide.
And after hauing whispered a space
Vnder a rocke that lyes a little space
Of dying people, during eight yeares space,
She fled into the wildernesse a space,
And welled goodly forth, that in short space
Her gentle speach applide, that in short space
And the wide sea importuned long space
But he them both outran a wondrous space,
And did it selfe diuide with equall space,
Her greedy eyes with gazing a long space:
A Ladie, seeming in so farre a space,
She in short space did often bring to nought
Did spend her dayes, and lov'd in forests wyld to space.
Thereat the Champions both stood still a space,
No longer space thereto he did desire,
